title: R45701
content: Congress has tried to determine the government's spending on homeland security, facing challenges due to the lack of a clear definition and the dispersed nature of homeland security activities. The Department of Homeland Security is not solely focused on homeland security missions, and other federal agencies also have responsibilities in this area. The concept of homeland security in U.S. policy evolved over the last two decades, with a focus on responding to terrorism and other threats. After the 9/11 attacks, new approaches were established, including the creation of a presidential council and department, and the issuance of presidential directives. The concept expanded to include disasters, public health emergencies, and other events that threaten the United States. The evolution of homeland security in U.S. policy includes responding to terrorism and other threats. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 established the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) to coordinate efforts involving military and civilian agencies at all levels of government. The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) was established in 2002 from components of 22 government agencies. It officially began operations in 2003 and has undergone restructurings to improve effectiveness. Some functions remain in original agencies, and not all DHS missions are strictly related to homeland security. Section 889 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 required the President's annual budget request to include an analysis of homeland security funding across the federal government. From FY2003 to FY2017, the U.S. government directed roughly $878 billion to preventing terrorist attacks, protecting critical infrastructure, and responding to incidents. Annual budget authority peaked at almost $74 billion in FY2009. The homeland security budget authority increased from $41 billion in FY2003 to almost $74 billion in FY2009. Annual budget authority for homeland security agencies ranged between $66 billion and $73 billion. The DHS budget rose from $31.2 billion in FY2003 to almost $68.4 billion in FY2017. The Trump Administration requested nearly $75 billion for DHS in FY2019, including funds for major disasters and additional funding for the Coast Guard. The FY2019 DHS annual appropriations act included almost $56 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority, with $12 billion for major disasters and $165 million for Coast Guard OCO funding. The current budget environment may pose challenges for homeland security programs and DHS due to ongoing capital investment efforts like the proposed border wall. Funding demands for capital investment, border security, and cybersecurity within DHS may compete for limited government funding. The Intelligence Community has improved integration and support for homeland security post-9/11, addressing barriers between intelligence and law enforcement for more effective coordination against threats. The 9/11 Commission identified barriers to information sharing that degraded U.S. national security. Legislation like the Homeland Security Act of 2002 and the Intelligence Reform and Terrorist Prevention Act of 2004 aimed to enhance information sharing and coordination in the government to combat terrorist threats. The National Counterterrorism Center and the Director of National Intelligence were established to improve strategic management across the Intelligence Community. New legal authorities accompanied these organizational changes. The 17 organizational elements of the IC underwent changes with new legal authorities. Initiatives at federal, state, and local levels include FBI-led JTTFs and DHS NNFC for improved collaboration. FBI/IB, DHS's OIA, and CG-2 are closely linked to homeland security within the IC. OIA combines information from various sources to analyze threats to the homeland. The OIA analytical products focus on threats like terrorism, border security, human trafficking, and public health. OIA serves customers ranging from the U.S. President to border patrol agents, Coast Guard personnel, and local first responders. The Coast Guard Intelligence (CG-2) enterprise is the intelligence component of the United States Coast Guard, providing analysis and products on maritime border security. The FBI/IB includes four component organizations: The Directorate of Intelligence oversees all FBI intelligence functions, the Office of Partner Engagement maintains intelligence sharing relationships, the Office of Private Sector conducts outreach to businesses impacted by threats, and the Bureau Intelligence Council provides a forum for senior-level dialogue on integrated security. The FBI's Bureau Intelligence Council facilitates senior-level dialogue on integrated assessments of domestic threats within the Intelligence Community. The Cyber Threat Intelligence Integration Center (CTIIC), established in 2015 under the Office of the DNI, provides all-source analysis of cyber threats to the United States, coordinating with other intelligence organizations for a unified effort in assessing and warning of cyber threats to the homeland. The importance of adhering to privacy and civil liberties protections in the Intelligence Community's efforts to assess and warn of cyber threats to the homeland has been underscored by organizational developments since 9/11. The focus has shifted from state-centric threats to nonstate actors, necessitating strict adherence to intelligence oversight rules and regulations, as well as annual training for the protection of privacy and civil liberties within the IC workforce. In the Department of Homeland Security, the Directorate of Science and Technology (S&T) is responsible for establishing and administering these efforts. The Department of Homeland Security's Directorate of Science and Technology (S&T) is primarily responsible for coordinating research and development activities, including those related to nuclear and radiological threats. Other DHS components, such as the Domestic Nuclear Detection Office (DNDO) and the Coast Guard, also fund R&D activities. Coordination, organization, and impact are key issues for DHS R&D in the 116th Congress. The Under Secretary for S&T and the Director of DNDO have statutory roles in coordinating homeland security R&D efforts. The Department of Homeland Security's Directorate of Science and Technology (S&T) is responsible for coordinating research and development activities, including nuclear detection R&D. Congressional interests in internal and external coordination have been long-standing. The Government Accountability Office (GAO) highlighted challenges in overseeing R&D department-wide in a 2012 report. In response, DHS was directed to implement new policies for R&D prioritization and review policies for defining and overseeing R&D department-wide. GAO reported in 2014 that DHS had updated its guidance for R&D but had not yet developed policy guidance for DHS-wide R&D oversight, coordination, and tracking. The Department of Homeland Security lacks a mechanism for capturing and understanding research and development activities conducted across various agencies, hindering external coordination. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 directs the Under Secretary for S&T to develop a government-wide national policy and strategic plan for homeland security R&D, but no such plan has been issued. Instead, the S&T Directorate has developed R&D plans with selected individual agencies. The National Science and Technology Council has issued government-wide R&D strategies in selected areas like biosurveillance. DHS reorganized its R&D activities by establishing the Countering Weapons of Mass Destruction Office in 2017. The 116th Congress may examine the implementation of the Countering Weapons of Mass Destruction Act of 2018. The organization of DHS laboratory facilities may also be a focus of attention in the 116th Congress. The Science and Technology Directorate in the 116th Congress acquired laboratories from various departments, including the Plum Island Animal Disease Center and the National Urban Security Technology Laboratory. The Federal Bureau of Investigation agreed to cover some operational costs of the National Biodefense Analysis and Countermeasures Center, and there were proposals to transfer operational responsibility for the National Bio and Agro-Defense Facility. The US faces a significant illegal drug market dominated by Mexican transnational criminal organizations, posing a major threat according to the DEA. The DEA states that Mexican transnational criminal organizations control smuggling corridors along the Southwest border and collaborate with other criminal networks. They transport drugs across the U.S.-Mexico border using various methods like tunnels, aircraft, and vehicles. TCOs also profit from human trafficking, weapons smuggling, counterfeiting, and extortion. Mexican drug traffickers collaborate with U.S. gangs to distribute illicit drugs in the United States, generating revenue for the gangs. They use various methods like bulk cash smuggling, money transfer systems, and virtual currencies like Bitcoin for money laundering. Gangs often work with different drug trafficking organizations and engage in a variety of criminal activities. Gangs collaborate with drug trafficking organizations, including Mexican traffickers, to sell various drugs in the U.S. The current drug threats include opioids like heroin and fentanyl, marijuana, methamphetamine, cocaine, and synthetic drugs. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) Administrator is tasked with creating a "national preparedness goal" (NPG) and developing a "national preparedness system" (NPS) to ensure the nation's ability to prevent, respond to, recover from, and mitigate natural disasters, terrorism, and other man-made disasters. This is guided by Presidential Policy Directive 8: National Preparedness (PPD-8), which replaced Homeland Security Presidential Directive 8: National Preparedness (HSPD-8). The NPS is supported by various strategic component policies, national planning frameworks, and federal interagency operational plans. The National Preparedness System (NPS) and its component policies outline the federal government's strategic vision for preparing the nation for all hazards. It identifies core capabilities needed to achieve the National Preparedness Goal (NPG) and defines core capabilities as necessary for preparing for incidents posing the greatest risk to national security. The National Preparedness System (NPS) includes annual National Preparedness Reports that track progress towards national preparedness objectives, using self-assessment processes like THIRA and SPR. The NPS influences budget decisions, assigns responsibilities, and sets long-term disaster preparedness policies. The Administration can update PPD-8 guidance, and Congress may oversee the NPS. Congress may oversee various factors related to the National Preparedness System (NPS), ensuring alignment with objectives outlined in the PKEMRA statute, informed by data and metrics, proper federal roles and resources allocation, incorporation of nonfederal resources, and appropriate allocation of resources relative to other homeland security missions. FEMA provides temporary housing assistance programs after disaster declarations, but limitations may hinder the transition to permanent housing. Congress should consider potential changes to the Stafford Act for better housing assistance. FEMA provides temporary housing assistance programs under the Stafford Act, including the Transitional Sheltering Assistance (TSA) program for disaster survivors. TSA offers short-term hotel/motel accommodations for individuals unable to return to their uninhabitable primary residence. Assistance lasts 5-14 days initially and can be extended up to 6 months. Challenges in transitioning to permanent housing were highlighted during Hurricane Maria. Some Hurricane Maria disaster survivors from Puerto Rico remained in the TSA program for nearly one year due to extensions, similar to survivors of Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Sandy. Research suggests that prolonged stays in emergency sheltering solutions like TSA may lead to adverse mental health outcomes. FEMA's Individuals and Households Program (IHP) may be a better option for interim housing needs. IHP assistance provides temporary lodging and housing accommodations for disaster survivors with uninsured or under-insured necessary expenses. Eligibility and program limitations exist, such as ineligibility for those with habitable primary residences or access to rent-free housing. Assistance is generally limited to 18 months but can be extended by FEMA. Challenges in providing financial and direct assistance post-disaster include lack of affordable housing, restrictions on rental payment rates adjustments, and limitations on MHU placements. Additionally, FEMA's direct lease assistance program is only offered in scarce rental resource areas. Restoring infrastructure, community services, and employment opportunities post-disaster also impact survivor relocation decisions. Following disasters, survivor relocation decisions may be influenced by available services, employment opportunities, and housing options. FEMA implemented the Disaster Housing Assistance Program (DHAP) in collaboration with HUD after Hurricanes Katrina, Rita, Ike, Gustav, and Sandy to provide rental assistance and case management services. DHAP, funded through the Disaster Relief Fund, offered more assistance for longer periods compared to the Individual Assistance program. Despite being recognized as a promising housing strategy, FEMA has not consistently implemented DHAP. FEMA has not implemented DHAP following recent disasters despite requests, citing better housing solutions and concerns about cost effectiveness. Clear definitions and processes may be needed to address disaster housing needs comprehensively. Congress may request an evaluation of FEMA's capacity. The Disaster Recovery Reform Act of 2018 (DRRA) requires Congress to evaluate FEMA's capacity to meet disaster survivors' needs, collaborate with housing partners for solutions, update the National Disaster Housing Strategy, and consider legislative solutions to address unmet needs. The Disaster Recovery Reform Act of 2018 (DRRA) is a comprehensive legislation focusing on improving disaster planning, response, and recovery, and increasing FEMA accountability. It amends the Stafford Act and applies to disasters declared after August 1, 2017. Congress may monitor the implementation of DRRA's requirements. The Disaster Recovery Reform Act of 2018 (DRRA) includes over 50 provisions for FEMA policy changes, reporting, and rulemaking with 2019 deadlines. Implementation is largely at FEMA's discretion, impacting disaster preparedness, response, and recovery. DRRA allows the President to allocate up to 6% of certain federal grant assistance for Predisaster Hazard Mitigation. The Disaster Recovery Reform Act of 2018 (DRRA) allows for a significant increase in federal grant assistance for Predisaster Hazard Mitigation, including grants for Public Assistance (PA) and Individual Assistance (IA) under the Stafford Act. This new funding mechanism has the potential to provide higher financial assistance to individuals and households, with the amount being significantly increased compared to previous limits. The implementation and management of this new funding by FEMA remains uncertain. Post-DRRA, financial assistance for repairs and replacement of housing and other needs assistance may not exceed $34,900 annually. Financial assistance for renting alternate housing is not capped. Changes post-DRRA may lead to increased spending on temporary disaster housing assistance and other needs assistance. FEMA may pilot some DRRA provisions, such as management costs for the PA Program and HMGP. Following the passage of DRRA, the PA management cost reimbursement rate increased to 12% of the total grant award, with 7% for the grantee and 5% for the subgrantee. The HMGP management cost reimbursement rate also increased to 15%, with 10% for the grantee and 5% for the subgrantee. Prior to DRRA, there was no pass-through requirement for subgrantees to receive a percentage of management costs. Some DRRA provisions may limit FEMA's ability to recoup assistance, including the potential waiver of debts owed in error. DRRA amends the statute of limitations on FEMA's ability to recover assistance, limiting the collection of debts owed in error and extending the time frame for initiating administrative actions. This change is significant as it allows for a longer period to close projects associated with disasters before recouping funds. The Disaster Recovery Reform Act (DRRA) includes reporting requirements that may influence decision-making regarding future disaster response and recovery. Reports were due within 90 days of DRRA's enactment, with some provisions also requiring briefings before the deadline. Other federal entities, such as the Office of Inspector General for the Department of Homeland Security, have specific responsibilities. Congress may evaluate FEMA's implementation of DRRA provisions, review the effectiveness of regulations and policy guidance, and assess changes to federal assistance for past and future disasters. The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) is the primary source of flood insurance coverage for residential properties in the United States. It aims to provide access to flood insurance, transfer financial risk to the federal government, and reduce the nation's flood risk through floodplain management standards. NFIP also works to reduce federal expenditure on disaster assistance after floods by engaging in noninsurance activities such as identifying flood hazards and disseminating flood-risk information. The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) identifies and maps flood hazards, disseminates flood-risk information, requires community land-use and building-code standards, contributes to community resilience by funding rebuilding after floods, and offers grants for flood-risk reduction. Managed by FEMA, NFIP has over 22,000 participating communities with 5.1 million policies providing $1.3 trillion in coverage. It collects $4.7 billion in annual revenue and is voluntary for communities to participate. Floods are the most common natural disaster in the US, and NFIP aims to reduce federal expenditure on disaster assistance. The NFIP requires communities to adopt land-use and control measures for access to flood insurance. FEMA sets minimum standards for participation, but enforcement is the responsibility of local governments. Communities collaborate with FEMA to develop Flood Insurance Rate Maps to reduce flood risk. Property owners in Special Flood Hazard Areas (SFHAs) must purchase flood insurance for federally backed mortgages. Non-compliance may result in ineligibility for disaster assistance. NFIP funding comes from policyholder payments, appropriations, borrowing, and reinsurance. The program can borrow money for extreme events. The NFIP can borrow money from the Treasury for extreme events, with borrowing limits increased after major hurricanes like Katrina, Rita, Wilma, Sandy, Harvey, Irma, and Maria. The program owed $24.6 billion at the start of the 2017 hurricane season, borrowing $5.825 billion to cover claims from Hurricane Harvey. Total claims paid in 2017 were approximately $10.5 billion. The NFIP borrowed $5.825 billion from the Treasury to cover claims from Hurricane Harvey, reaching its borrowing limit. Congress canceled $16 billion of NFIP debt to pay claims for Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria. FEMA borrowed an additional $6.1 billion, bringing the debt to $20.525 billion. As of November 2018, $117 million was paid in claims for Hurricanes Florence and Michael. The NFIP has $9.9 billion in remaining borrowing authority as of January 2019. The NFIP's debt is owed by current and future participants, with $2.82 billion in principal repayments and $4.2 billion in interest paid since 2005. The NFIP debt was canceled in October 2017, totaling $16 billion. Congress has enacted 10 short-term NFIP reauthorizations since the end of FY2017. The NFIP is authorized until May 31, 2019, with no comprehensive expiration provision. If not reauthorized by Congress, new flood insurance contracts will expire, and the NFIP's borrowing authority will be reduced to $1 billion. The Community Disaster Loan (CDL) program, administered by FEMA, helps local governments with financial liquidity after disasters through structured loans that can be converted to grants. Non-traditional CDL programs were developed after Hurricanes Rita and Katrina in 2005. Non-traditional CDL programs were developed in response to Hurricanes Rita and Katrina in 2005, and for Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands following Hurricanes Harvey, Irma, and Maria in 2017. This Insight provides an overview of traditional and non-traditional CDLs and the policy issues they may raise in the 116th Congress, particularly with regard to CDL-type instruments developed for Puerto Rico and USVI.
